title: Web Scrapping with scrapy
text:
Hello! In this blog post I will go over how to create a web scrapper using scrapy. For the purpose of this post, the goal of our web scrapper is to find all actors from a particular movie and output the list the actors along with all other movies or TV shows they have been in. The website we will be webscrapping is www.themoviedb.org, which is a website that holds movie and TV show information.


The first step is to include the neccesary packages. When I was creating this webscrapper, I had issues with 403 errors. Therefore, I used a proxy via ScrapeOps to help resolve the errors and successfully scrape the websites.

import scrapy
from urllib.parse import urlencode

API_KEY = "816aed8f-f731-424c-b089-7c03af87389e"


def get_scrapeops_url(url):
    payload = {'api_key': API_KEY, 'url': url}
    proxy_url = 'https://proxy.scrapeops.io/v1/?' + urlencode(payload)
    return proxy_url

The get_scrapeops_url function will serve as a proxy and we can input a normal url into the function and it allow for us to not get flagged.



Now that we have inlcuded everything neccessary, we can start building our Spider class from scrapy. First we need to declare the class and the definite the constructor function init which would define the starting url that we are trying to scrape.

class TmdbSpider(scrapy.Spider):
    name = 'tmdb_spider'

    def __init__(self, subdir=None, *args, **kwargs):
        self.start_urls = [get_scrapeops_url(f"https://www.themoviedb.org/movie/{subdir}/")]

As we can see, the we created the TmbdSpider class and named it ‘tmbd_spider’ and used the proxy to build our constructor. The {subdir} portion of the URL is what movie we are trying to scrape. For example, my favorie moive is Interstellar, so subdir will be defined as 157336-interstellar, since the full URL is https://www.themoviedb.org/movie/157336-interstellar.
Next, we need to define our parse function, which will take our spider web scrapper to the cast and crew section of our movie.

def parse(self, response):
   """
   Parses the response from the main page of a movie on www.themoviedb.org.

   Assumptions:
   - Assumes that the response is from the main page of a movie on www.themoviedb.org.

   Effects:
   - Navigates to the Full Cast & Crew page of the movie.
   - Yields a scrapy.Request to parse the full credits page of the movie.

   Args:
      response: The response object containing the main page's HTML.

   Yields:
      scrapy.Request: A request to parse the full credits page of the movie.
   """
   # Navigate to the Full Cast & Crew page
   full_credits_url = response.url + '/cast/'
   yield scrapy.Request(full_credits_url , callback=self.parse_full_credits)

On themoviedb webstite, once we are on our movie’s website (i.e. https://www.themoviedb.org/movie/157336-interstellar), if we click on the Full Cast and Crew button we are redirected to the cast page with the following URL: https://www.themoviedb.org/movie/157336-interstellar/cast. As we can see, the only difference between this URL and the previous is the added /cast at the end. Therefore, we will yeid the same URL as before and make sure to add the /cast/ the URL, so that we are now navigated to the Full Cast and Crew page.



Next we will implement the parse_full_credits function of our spider class. The goal of this function will be to retrieve all the actor links for the actors in our movie. On the movie database website, each actor has their own page which lists information about thier bio, acting credits, and more. For example, the lead actor in Interstellar has the following page on TMDB: https://www.themoviedb.org/person/10297-matthew-mcconaughey. Here is the implementation of the parse_full_credits method:

def parse_full_credits(self, response):
        """
        Parses the full credits page of a movie on www.themoviedb.org to retrieve actor links.

        Assumptions:
        - Assumes that the response is from the full credits page of a movie on www.themoviedb.org.

        Effects:
        - Extracts actor links from the page.
        - Yields scrapy.Requests to parse each actor's page.

        Args:
            response: The response object containing the full credits page's HTML.

        Yields:
            scrapy.Request: Requests to parse each actor's page.
        """
        # Extract actor links and yield requests for each actor's page
        actor_links = response.css('div.info > p > a::attr(href)').getall()
        for actor_link in actor_links:
            yield scrapy.Request(get_scrapeops_url("https://www.themoviedb.org" + actor_link), callback=self.parse_actor_page)

If we look at few of the pages on TMDB website, we notice that every acting page had the same starting URL: https://www.themoviedb.org. Therefore, we need to find what follows this URL, which we call actor_link, then add it to the starting URL, which will give the full URL for the acting page.
By going on the initial movie’s website and using the developer’s tools, I was able to find that link to every actor in the movie was listed in there. By following the path from div.info to p to a::attr(href), we are able to extract the second half the URL that we need.
Thus, we can yield the full URL for each actor in the movie.



Finally, we need to implement our final function, the parse_actor_page function. The goal of this function to go through each of the actor’s page and extract all the movies and TV shows that they have appeared in. We will then yield the name of the actor and the list of movies and TV shows.
Let’s first go over how to extract the name of the actor. The beggining of the parse_actor_page looks like this:


def parse_actor_page(self, response):
        """
        Parses an actor's page on www.themoviedb.org to retrieve their name and movie/TV show credits.

        Assumptions:
        - Assumes that the response is from an actor's page on www.themoviedb.org.

        Effects:
        - Extracts the actor's name and their movie/TV show credits.
        - Yields the actor's name and their credited movie/TV show.

        Args:
            response: The response object containing the actor's page's HTML.

        Yields:
            dict: A dictionary containing the actor's name and their credited movie/TV show.
        """

        # Extract actor name and movies/TV shows they have worked in
        actor_name = response.css('head > title::text').get()

        # Extract only the part before the hyphen
        actor_name = actor_name.split('—')[0].strip()

Using the developer’s tools again, I was able to see that every actor’s page had their name listed in the source code under, first under the head section, then under the title section. Therefore, the selector response.css(‘head > title::text’).get(), would retrieve the title of the webpage. However, this response includes the title of the website. So for example, for Matthew McConaughey, the selector would give the following response: “Matthew McConaughey — The Movie Database (TMDB)”. Therefore we need to cut off everything from the long dash,‘—’, and onwards. By using the split function with ‘—’ and selecting the first half the split, [0], we are able to isolate the name of the actor. We will store this value in the variable actor_name.
Next, we need to implement the second half the function that will extract the movie and TV names for every actor. Here is the full implementation of the parse_actor_page function, with the second half of the function:

def parse_actor_page(self, response):
        """
        Parses an actor's page on www.themoviedb.org to retrieve their name and movie/TV show credits.

        Assumptions:
        - Assumes that the response is from an actor's page on www.themoviedb.org.

        Effects:
        - Extracts the actor's name and their movie/TV show credits.
        - Yields the actor's name and their credited movie/TV show.

        Args:
            response: The response object containing the actor's page's HTML.

        Yields:
            dict: A dictionary containing the actor's name and their credited movie/TV show.
        """
        # Extract actor name and movies/TV shows they have worked in
        actor_name = response.css('head > title::text').get()

        # Extract only the part before the hyphen
        actor_name = actor_name.split('—')[0].strip()

       # Find the index of 'Acting' in the list of credits
        acting_index = response.xpath('//div[@class="credits_list"]/h3/text()').getall().index('Acting')

        # Select the element corresponding to 'Acting' and its associated table
        acting_only = response.xpath(f'(//div[@class="credits_list"]/table[@class="card credits"])[{acting_index + 1}]')

        # Extract movie or TV names from the selected table
        movie_or_TV_name = acting_only.xpath('.//a[@class="tooltip"]/bdi/text()').getall()


        for movie_or_TV_name in movie_or_TV_name:
            yield {
                "actor":actor_name,
                "movie_or_TV_name": movie_or_TV_name
            }

This part was a bit tricky as we want to make sure that we only select movies and TV shows in which the person’s page that we are personing were credited in an acting role, as some also have production and other credits that we do not want included in the list.
In order to do this we must take advantage of the indexing in source code that will allow us to select only the acting roles. After looking an the source code on the page, we can see that all the acting roles for an actor had a line in common before listing all acting roles:
<h3 class=“zero”>Acting<>

Therefore we can use the follwoing xpath response to find the index for each actor:

response.xpath('//div[@class="credits_list"]/h3/text()').getall().index('Acting')

We will store this index under the variable name actor_index.
Next we must use this variable to find the table on the actors page that corresponds to the acting index. Thus we can use the following to return this section of the table under the acting index.

response.xpath(f'(//div[@class="credits_list"]/table[@class="card credits"])[{acting_index + 1}]')

The reason we must add the +1 to acting_index is that xpath starts its index at 1 instead of 0. Therefore we must account for this change by adding the one.
The final stage of our extraction is to go through the table we selected and retrieve the title of each movie or TV show that the actor appears in.
Using the inspect element tool again, we can see that information is located under the <a class = “tooltip”> section, with the text of the film being wrapped by the <bdi> markers.
Therefore, we can use the followig line to get all the titles of the films and shows, as we are already under the acting table of the page. Therefore movie_or_TV_name will be a list of the credits for each actor.

acting_only.xpath('.//a[@class="tooltip"]/bdi/text()').getall()

Finally, we yield the actors name and the credited film or TV show under the names “actor” and “movie_or_TV_show”, so when we export to a CSV file they will be the name of our columns.
Now that we have completed our spider class, we can run our code and output to a CSV file called output. Therefore we must run the following line in our terminal.
scrapy crawl tmdb_spider -o output.csv -a subdir=157336-interstellar
This will create an output called output.csv, we can read this file into a Pandas dataframe to view our data.



Now that we have our output we can convert the csv file into a Pandas dataframe to view and analyze our data. In a seperate file we can import Pandas and run the following line of code:

import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv("output.csv")

df.info()

---  ------            --------------  ----- 
 0   actor             2063 non-null   object
 1   movie_or_TV_name  2063 non-null   object
dtypes: object(2)
memory usage: 32.4+ KB

We can see that Matthew McConaughey is the first actor in our list and we can see his associated roles, for example “The Lost Bus” and “Come Home” are a couple of his roles.
Next we can see compute a sorted list with the top movies and TV shows that share actors from the movie Interstellar.
First we need to count the data by the tile of the role:

counted = df["movie_or_TV_name"].value_counts()
counted

As we can see the movie that we based our web crawler on appears first, so we should drop that from the list.

counted = counted.drop(counted.index[0])

Next, in order to for us to work with this data easier we must convert the Pandas series into a Pandas Data Frame and reset the index.

counted = counted.to_frame()
counted.reset_index(inplace=True)

We will also renmae the columns to Movie or Show Title and Number of Shared Actors.

counted = counted.rename(columns={"movie_or_TV_name":"Movie or Show Title", "count":"Number of Shared Actors"})

Now we can use plotly to create a bar graph of the some of the most common shared movies or TV shows among the actors in Interstellar. Since there are 1753 movies or TV shows, we will only pick the top 15 titles to display.

import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.io as pio

pio.renderers.default = 'iframe'


import plotly.express as px

top_counted = counted.head(15)

# Create a bar chart using Plotly
fig = px.bar(top_counted, x='Movie or Show Title', y='Number of Shared Actors', title='Number of Shared Actors per Movie or Show')

# Show the plot
fig.show()




As we can see, the top shared movies and shows are displayed in an interactive bar graph format, where if we hover over the bar we can exactly how many shared actors there are. The results are somewhat expected as well. We can see a majority of the shared titles are from late night shows or talk shows. This makes sense, as actors and celebrities often appear on these shows. Since Interstellar has a good amount of famous actors that would appear on these shows, the top results are something that we expect.
Other top shared roles are Inside “Interstellar”, which is a documentary on how the film was made, so it would make sense that a lot of the actors from Interstellar would appear in the documentary.
Another film of note is The Dark Knight Rises. This film, along with Interstellar, was directed by Christopher Nolan, and he is know for using some of the same actors in his films. Therefore it is not suprising to see one of his films on this list.



For our second data analysis, we can find the number of roles that each actor has been in and then display a bar graph to visualize the data.
We will count the number of roles and then sort by highest of number of roles. We will use plotly again to produce the graph.

# Count number of roles and sort by highest number
roles_count = df.groupby('actor').size().reset_index(name='Number of Roles')

roles_count = roles_count.sort_values(by='Number of Roles', ascending=False)

# Create a bar chart using Plotly
fig = px.bar(roles_count, x='actor', y='Number of Roles', title='Number of Roles for Each Actor')

# Show the plot
fig.show()




We can see that the interactive bar graph is displayed. The results are also what we expected. The actor with (by far) the highest number of roles is Michael Caine, with 224 roles. This is not suprising as Michael Caine is one of the oldest actors and has had a very long career in the film industry.
We can also see Matt Damon, Matthew McConaughey, and Anne Hathaway have the fourth, fifth, and sixth top roles. These are famous contemporary actors who have appeared in many famous films as well as have had very successfull careers. Therefore it is not suprising to see them near the top of the list.



Thank you for reading my blog post! I hope that you were able to learn more about web scrapping as well as how to display scrapped data.

title: Web Development with Flask
Web Development with Flask
text:
Our goal is to create a website using Flask, a python package, thats main purpose is to be a message board. We want the website to have the functionaility of having users being able to post messages to the messages board. When the users want to post a message, they should be prompted with two fields: one for their name and one for their message.
Next, we want a user to be able to view messages of the message board as well. When the user wants to view messages they should see a defined number of random messages from the message board.
Finally, we want to add some style to our website using CSS so the website is not boring and can be more engaging.

title: Web Development with Flask
text:
First we need to include our neccesary packages into our main file, called app.py.
Will also create our app, named app, that uses flask.

import sqlite3
import pandas as pd

from flask import Flask, g, render_template, request

app = Flask(__name__)

title: Web Development with Flask
text:
Next, using sqlite, we will create and host a database. This database will contain all the messages that different users submit to our message board. This database will also be used later on to display some of the messages when the user choses to view messages.
Here is how the function, get_message_db(), is defined:

def get_message_db():
    try:
        return g.message_db
    except AttributeError:
        g.message_db = sqlite3.connect("messages_db.sqlite")
        cursor = g.message_db.cursor()
        
        # Create the messages table if it doesn't exist
        cmd = 'CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS messages (name TEXT, message TEXT);'
        cursor.execute(cmd)
        g.message_db.commit()
        
        return g.message_db

We can see that at first we try to access the database. If it not is created then we get an attribuite error so we will connect to sqlite and create our database.
We then create a cursor using the .cursor() function that will allow us to use SQL code to create our database.
We then use CREATE TABLE to make our table called messaages. This table has two columns, name and message, as these are the only things that user is able to submit to the website.
Finally, we execute and commit the SQL code and then return the database.

title: Web Development with Flask
text:
We wil next go over how to insert user messages into the database that we just created. We will do this by using the insert_messages() function. This function takes in one variable, request. From request we can access the name and the message that we want to insert into the database. We will be going how we got the request later on when we go over our routes.
Here is the defintion for our insert_messages() function:

def insert_message(request):
    # Get the message and the name
    message = request.form['message']
    name = request.form["name"]
    db = get_message_db()
    cursor = db.cursor()
    print("here")
    # Insert the data into our database
    cursor.execute('INSERT INTO messages (name, message) VALUES (?, ?)', (name, message))
    db.commit()
    cursor.close()
    db.close()
    return message, name

In the function we first extract the message and name from the request and store them under the same variable names.
Next, use our previous function to get the database and store as the variable db.
Then we use the cursur to write an SQL command to insert the message and name as a tuple into our database.
Make sure to close the cursor and databse, and then we return the tuple as well.

title: Web Development with Flask
text:
Our last main function we need to implement is the random messages function. The goal of this function is to retrieve an n amount of random messages from our database. We will later use this function to display these messages on the website.
The function is defined as the following:

def random_messages(n):
    # Connect to database
    db = get_message_db()
    cursor = db.cursor()

    # Find n random messages
    cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM messages ORDER BY RANDOM() LIMIT ?", (n,))
    random_messages = cursor.fetchall()

    # Close database
    cursor.close()
    db.close()

    return random_messages

We can see we use the same idea as before, connecting to the database with the cursor. The main part of this function is using the ORDER BY and RANDOM() SQL commands to grab the first n tuples in the database. Since we are using RANDOM() then these n tuples will be different every time and ensures randomness.
Finally, we close the database and return the random messages.

title: Data Visualization and Databases
text:
Hello! Welcome to this blog post where I will go over how to use databases for data visualization. For this post we will be using example data of temperature data from various different countries.


First we need to run the following line of code:

import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.io as pio

pio.renderers.default = 'iframe'


For this post, we are going to be using SQL queries in order to retrevie our data. Then we are going to use some data visualization software to answer a few questions. We will be using sqlite to establish a database and to retreive our data.



In a seperate file, I already loaded in the data into a database named “database.db”. Thus we will connect to this database in order to get information about our data. The data we are using consists of three different tables: stations, countries, and temperatures. This data has been collected and shows the temperature readings of different stations in various countries over the years.
We will use this data to answer our first question: How does the average yearly change in temperature vary within a given country?
Thus we need to use an SQL query to acess the data that is useful for answering this question.
We will also need to include the headers necessary for the rest of the post.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import sqlite3
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
import plotly.express as px

Here is the query we will use. The function allows a user a to input a database file, country, year_begin, year_end, and month to find the data needed to answer our question.

def query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month):
    with sqlite3.connect(db_file) as conn:
        cmd = f"""
            SELECT
                stations.NAME,
                stations.LATITUDE,
                stations.LONGITUDE,
                countries.Name AS Country,
                temperatures.Year,
                temperatures.Month,
                temperatures.Temp
            FROM
                temperatures
            JOIN
                stations ON temperatures.ID = stations.ID
            JOIN
                countries ON SUBSTR(stations.ID, 1, 2) = SUBSTR(countries."FIPS 10-4", 1, 2)
            WHERE
                countries.Name = '{country}'
                AND temperatures.Year BETWEEN {year_begin} AND {year_end}
                AND temperatures.Month = {month}
        """

        # Execute the query and read the results into a DataFrame
        result_df = pd.read_sql_query(cmd, conn)
    conn.close()
    return result_df

Now in our dataframe we have the data that we will use the answer our question: the station’s name, latitude, and longitude, the country’s name, and the tempature of the country and the month we are looking at. This data is stored in result_df.
Thus, we can now write a fucntion, temperature_coefficient_plot to use the pulled data and make a plot. The goal of this function is to create a plot of the selected country with a scatter of data points located at the stations used. Each datapoint will store information about the average yearly change in temperature for the associated station.
The function uses the same variables as the previous function, in addition to mins_obs, zoom, mapbox_style, and color_continuous_scale. mins_obs is an inputed variable that only shows stations that have at least mins_obs years of observatoin. The other variables, zoom, mapbox_style, and color_continuous_scale, are for graphing preference of the plot.

def temperature_coefficient_plot(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month, min_obs, zoom =2, mapbox_style="carto-positron", color_continuous_scale=px.colors.diverging.RdGy_r ):
    df = query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month)

    grouped_df = df.groupby("NAME")

    dfs_dict = {name: group for name, group in grouped_df}

    filtered_dfs_dict = {name: group_df for name, group_df in dfs_dict.items() if len(group_df) >= min_obs}

    def coef(data_group):
        x = data_group[["Year"]]
        y = data_group["Temp"]
        LR = LinearRegression()
        LR.fit(x, y)
        return LR.coef_[0]

    results = pd.DataFrame()
    for name, filtered_df in filtered_dfs_dict.items():
        temp_change = filtered_df.groupby("NAME").apply(coef).reset_index(name='temp_change')
    
        latitude = filtered_df["LATITUDE"].iloc[0]
        longitude = filtered_df["LONGITUDE"].iloc[0]

        result_row = pd.DataFrame({
            "NAME": [name],
            "LATITUDE": [latitude],
            "LONGITUDE": [longitude],
            "EXPECTED_CHANGE": [temp_change["temp_change"].iloc[0]]
        })

        results = results._append(result_row, ignore_index=True)

    fig = px.scatter_mapbox(
    results,
    lat="LATITUDE",
    lon="LONGITUDE",
    text="NAME",
    color="EXPECTED_CHANGE",
    color_continuous_scale=color_continuous_scale,
    size_max=30,
    zoom=zoom,
    mapbox_style=mapbox_style,
    title=f"Expected Temperature Change in {country} ({year_begin}-{year_end}), Month {month}",
    )

    fig.show()

The function first pulls the df using the query_climate_database function, then groups the results by station name.
This is what the data frame would look like after being grouped.

grouped_df = df.groupby("NAME")

Next, the function creates a seperate dataframe for each station that contains all that stations data. It also filters out any statoins with less than mins_obs years of data. It will store these dataframes in a dictionary where the key will be the name of the station.
Now that we have the dictionary of station’s data, we use linear regression from the scikit.learn libray, to fit a line of best fit for each station. Thus, the slope of this line will be the rate of change for the temperature at the given station. We will put each station and its rate of change in a seperate dataframe along with the station longitude and latitude. This information will be stored in a dataframe called results.
So the list of the rates of change will look like the following.

# create dictionary for dataframes, each keyed by the unique "NAME"
dfs_dict = {name: group for name, group in grouped_df}

filtered_dfs_dict = {name: group_df for name, group_df in dfs_dict.items() if len(group_df) >= min_obs}

#calculate expected change in temp for each station
def coef(data_group):
    x = data_group[["Year"]]
    y = data_group["Temp"]
    LR = LinearRegression()
    LR.fit(x, y)
    return LR.coef_[0]

First we need to run the following line of code:

import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.io as pio

pio.renderers.default = 'iframe'


For this post, we are going to be using SQL queries in order to retrevie our data. Then we are going to use some data visualization software to answer a few questions. We will be using sqlite to establish a database and to retreive our data.

title: Data Visualization and Databases
text:
In a seperate file, I already loaded in the data into a database named “database.db”. Thus we will connect to this database in order to get information about our data. The data we are using consists of three different tables: stations, countries, and temperatures. This data has been collected and shows the temperature readings of different stations in various countries over the years.
We will use this data to answer our first question: How does the average yearly change in temperature vary within a given country?
Thus we need to use an SQL query to acess the data that is useful for answering this question.
We will also need to include the headers necessary for the rest of the post.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import sqlite3
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
import plotly.express as px

Here is the query we will use. The function allows a user a to input a database file, country, year_begin, year_end, and month to find the data needed to answer our question.

def query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month):
    with sqlite3.connect(db_file) as conn:
        cmd = f"""
            SELECT
                stations.NAME,
                stations.LATITUDE,
                stations.LONGITUDE,
                countries.Name AS Country,
                temperatures.Year,
                temperatures.Month,
                temperatures.Temp
            FROM
                temperatures
            JOIN
                stations ON temperatures.ID = stations.ID
            JOIN
                countries ON SUBSTR(stations.ID, 1, 2) = SUBSTR(countries."FIPS 10-4", 1, 2)
            WHERE
                countries.Name = '{country}'
                AND temperatures.Year BETWEEN {year_begin} AND {year_end}
                AND temperatures.Month = {month}
        """

        # Execute the query and read the results into a DataFrame
        result_df = pd.read_sql_query(cmd, conn)
    conn.close()
    return result_df

Now in our dataframe we have the data that we will use the answer our question: the station’s name, latitude, and longitude, the country’s name, and the tempature of the country and the month we are looking at. This data is stored in result_df.
Thus, we can now write a fucntion, temperature_coefficient_plot to use the pulled data and make a plot. The goal of this function is to create a plot of the selected country with a scatter of data points located at the stations used. Each datapoint will store information about the average yearly change in temperature for the associated station.
The function uses the same variables as the previous function, in addition to mins_obs, zoom, mapbox_style, and color_continuous_scale. mins_obs is an inputed variable that only shows stations that have at least mins_obs years of observatoin. The other variables, zoom, mapbox_style, and color_continuous_scale, are for graphing preference of the plot.

def temperature_coefficient_plot(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month, min_obs, zoom =2, mapbox_style="carto-positron", color_continuous_scale=px.colors.diverging.RdGy_r ):
    df = query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month)

    grouped_df = df.groupby("NAME")

    dfs_dict = {name: group for name, group in grouped_df}

    filtered_dfs_dict = {name: group_df for name, group_df in dfs_dict.items() if len(group_df) >= min_obs}

    def coef(data_group):
        x = data_group[["Year"]]
        y = data_group["Temp"]
        LR = LinearRegression()
        LR.fit(x, y)
        return LR.coef_[0]

    results = pd.DataFrame()
    for name, filtered_df in filtered_dfs_dict.items():
        temp_change = filtered_df.groupby("NAME").apply(coef).reset_index(name='temp_change')
    
        latitude = filtered_df["LATITUDE"].iloc[0]
        longitude = filtered_df["LONGITUDE"].iloc[0]

        result_row = pd.DataFrame({
            "NAME": [name],
            "LATITUDE": [latitude],
            "LONGITUDE": [longitude],
            "EXPECTED_CHANGE": [temp_change["temp_change"].iloc[0]]
        })

        results = results._append(result_row, ignore_index=True)

    fig = px.scatter_mapbox(
    results,
    lat="LATITUDE",
    lon="LONGITUDE",
    text="NAME",
    color="EXPECTED_CHANGE",
    color_continuous_scale=color_continuous_scale,
    size_max=30,
    zoom=zoom,
    mapbox_style=mapbox_style,
    title=f"Expected Temperature Change in {country} ({year_begin}-{year_end}), Month {month}",
    )

    fig.show()

The function first pulls the df using the query_climate_database function, then groups the results by station name.

section: Question 3: How does the temperature vary across different latitudes within a specific country for a given month?
text:
Question 3: How does the temperature vary across different latitudes within a specific country for a given month?
This next question we try to answer is intruiging as we can see if there is a correlation between latitude and temperature for a country within a given month.
We first must define our new query function, query_temperature_by_latitude, which requires a user to input a county and a month to be visualized.
The query returns the name and latitude of the station as well as the average temperature for the selected station.

def query_temperature_by_latitude(db_file, country, month):
    with sqlite3.connect(db_file) as conn:
        cmd = f"""
            SELECT
                stations.NAME,
                stations.LATITUDE,
                AVG(temperatures.Temp) AS AvgTemperature
            FROM
                temperatures
            JOIN
                stations ON temperatures.ID = stations.ID
            JOIN
                countries ON SUBSTR(stations.ID, 1, 2) = SUBSTR(countries."FIPS 10-4", 1, 2)
            WHERE
                countries.Name = '{country}'
                AND temperatures.Month = {month}
            GROUP BY
                stations.NAME, stations.LATITUDE
            ORDER BY
                stations.LATITUDE
        """

        result_df = pd.read_sql_query(cmd, conn)

    return result_df

Next, we define our function plot_temperature_by_latitude, that will give us the scatter plot of all the stations used.
The function again uses the plotly library to produce the graph.

def plot_temperature_by_latitude(db_file, country, month):
    result_df = query_temperature_by_latitude(db_file, country, month)

    if result_df.empty:
        print("No data available for the specified parameters.")
        return

    fig = px.scatter(
        result_df,
        x="LATITUDE",
        y="AvgTemperature",
        color="AvgTemperature",
        size_max=20, 
        title=f"Temperature Variation by Latitude in {country}, Month {month}",
        labels={"LATITUDE": "Latitude", "AvgTemperature": "Average Temperature"},
        hover_name="NAME",
    )

    fig.show()

Now that we have defined our plotting function, let’s plot the temperatures in the United States and see if we can find any interesting trends.

plot_temperature_by_latitude(db_file, "United States", 3)




As we can see in the plot, there is a clear trend in the United States. As latitude inrcreaes, the average temperature decreases. This intuitively makes sense as we see that the stations in Hawaii are the warmest, while the stations in Alaska are the coldest. This placement is correct as we know that Hawaii is one of the hotest states and Alaska one of the coldest.
The graph is also interactive as the user is able to hover over each scatterpoint on the graph and check its latitude and average temperature. There is also a color coded scale on the right that shows the warmer stations as warm colors (yellow, orange) and the colder staions as cold colors (purple, blue).
